title: While Loops
description: Repeat code as long as a condition is true

content.text: While loops repeat code as long as a condition stays True. They're perfect when you don't know in advance how many times you need to loop.

content.code:
count = 0

while count < 5:
    print(f"Count is {count}")
    count = count + 1  # Don't forget this!

print("Done!")
content.explanation: The loop checks the condition before each iteration. When count reaches 5, the condition becomes False and the loop stops.

content.text: Always make sure your while loop condition will eventually become False, or you'll create an infinite loop that never stops!

content.code:
countdown = 5

while countdown > 0:
    print(countdown)
    countdown = countdown - 1

print("Blast off!")
content.explanation: We decrease countdown each time. When it hits 0, the condition (countdown > 0) becomes False and we exit the loop.

content.text: The 'break' statement exits a loop immediately:

content.code:
# Find the first number divisible by 7
num = 50

while num < 100:
    if num % 7 == 0:
        print(f"Found it: {num}")
        break  # Exit the loop
    num = num + 1

print(f"Final value: {num}")
content.explanation: When we find a number divisible by 7, break stops the loop immediately. This is useful when you're searching for something!

content.text: The 'continue' statement skips to the next iteration:

content.code:
# Print odd numbers from 1 to 10
num = 0

while num < 10:
    num = num + 1
    
    if num % 2 == 0:  # If even
        continue  # Skip the rest, go to next iteration
    
    print(num)  # Only prints odd numbers
content.explanation: continue skips the rest of the loop body and goes back to check the condition. Use it to skip certain iterations.

content.text: Be careful with continue - make sure you update your counter BEFORE the continue, or you might create an infinite loop!

content.code:
# Note: This simulates what would happen with real input
attempts = 0
max_attempts = 3

while attempts < max_attempts:
    # In real Python, you'd use: password = input("Enter password: ")
    password = "wrong"  # Simulating wrong password
    attempts = attempts + 1
    
    if password == "secret":
        print("Access granted!")
        break
    else:
        remaining = max_attempts - attempts
        print(f"Wrong! {remaining} attempts left")

if attempts == max_attempts:
    print("Locked out!")
content.explanation: This pattern is common for retry logic. We limit attempts and break when successful.

content.code:
# Keep doubling until > 100
value = 1

while True:  # Runs forever unless we break
    print(value)
    value = value * 2
    
    if value > 100:
        break

print(f"Final value: {value}")
content.explanation: 'while True' creates an infinite loop. You MUST use break to exit it. This pattern is useful when your exit condition is in the middle of the loop.

content.text: Use for loops when you know how many times to loop. Use while loops when you're looping until a condition changes.
Accumulating values in a while loop:

content.code:
# Sum numbers from 1 to 10
total = 0
num = 1

while num <= 10:
    total = total + num
    num = num + 1

print(f"Sum: {total}")  # 55
content.explanation: We build up the total by adding each number. This pattern works for sums, products, or building lists.

content.prompt: Write a while loop that prints all numbers from 1 to 20, but only if they're NOT divisible by 3. Use continue to skip multiples of 3.
content.hint: Increment num first, then check if it's divisible by 3 (num % 3 == 0). Use continue to skip printing those numbers.
